newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: N.Ireland to "safe hands" Burke in Irish cabinet.
newsitem.headline: N.Ireland to "safe hands" Burke in Irish cabinet.

text.p: Northern Ireland, the most contentious issue on the agenda of any Irish government, was entrusted to 53-year-old Ray Burke when Prime Minister Bertie Ahern appointed him Foreign Affairs minister on Thursday.
"He's a safe pair of hands, a very astute man who does not make mistakes in parliament. He weighs his words. It's a clever appointment," one political contemporary said.
Burke was Foreign Affairs spokesman in opposition and has served as Minister for Justice and Communication, Industry and Commerce and Energy and Communications between 1987 and 1991.
His promotion by Ahern is reward for a stalwart of the Fianna Fail party, the biggest in Irish politics, and for a political associate linked to his power base in North Dublin.
Burke, Ahern and former Prime Minister Charles Haughey were the leaders of what was jokingly referred to as Fianna Fail's "North Dublin mafia" in the 1980s and 1990s.
It was a powerful bloc in the party but it lost its ascendancy when Albert Reynolds came to power until his coalition collapsed in late 1994.

Reynolds brought with him his own coterie of supporters but when he was forced to step down in a scandal over legal appointments it brought Ahern, then Finance Minister, to the leadership of the party and marked Burke's return.

Burke's promotion will put him in the public eye as often as Ahern as Ireland and its British partners seek to keep alive a peace process for Northern Ireland in which Reynolds had a shaping hand in late 1993.

Long-stalled by mistrust between Northern Ireland's pro-British Protestant Unionists and pro-Irish nationalists, the year-old talks received an injection of fresh political thinking on Wednesday from the new British government.

British Prime Minister Tony Blair gave Sinn Fein, political wing of Irish Republican Army guerrillas, a formal offer to join Belfast peace talks if the IRA calls an end to its war against British rule of Northern Ireland.

Burke's task, political sources said, will be to maximise the opportunity to solve the biggest and oldest problem on Ireland's political agenda and to build a solid working relationship with Blair's administration.
Fianna Fail sees itself as the natural party of Irish republicans who want to see a united Ireland but has put a cool distance between itself and Sinn Fein because of IRA violence.

Burke will have to steer a course between championing the rights of the Catholic pro-Irish minority in Northern Ireland while pressing the IRA to abandon for good the guerrilla war which lies at the heart of the Northern Ireland conflict.
He succeeds Dick Spring, probably Ireland's best-known international figure after President Mary Robinson, who worked with the previous British government of John Major.
As Foreign Affairs minister he represents Ireland in a standing Anglo-Irish conference which oversees the peace process and Northern Ireland affairs since 1985.
